channel.title: NYT > Books > Book Review

item.title: Book Review: ‘Strangers,’ by Belle Burden
item.description: Born into exceptional privilege, Belle Burden had it all: love, money, family. Then her marriage fell apart.
item.dc:creator: Alex Kuczynski
item.category: Strangers: A Memoir of a Marriage (Book)
item.media:description: The author, far right, with Brooke Astor and her stepmother, Susan Burden, in 1999.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Hitch,’ by Sara Levine
item.description: Sara Levine’s “The Hitch” is a winningly zany portrait of a know-it-all whose beliefs are tested by a supernatural intrusion at a family visit.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs

item.title: Swoony Romance Books That Feel Like You’re on Vacation
item.description: Swoony reads will transport you from the doldrums of winter to a Caribbean resort, a Hamptons beach, the streets of Paris and more.
item.dc:creator: Ali Rosen
item.media:credit: The New York Times; author photo by Melanie Dunea

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Cradle of Citizenship,’ by James Traub
item.description: In “The Cradle of Citizenship,” the journalist James Traub finds that the biggest crisis in education is not what kids are learning, but whether they’re learning anything at all.
item.dc:creator: Mark Lilla
item.category: The Cradle of Citizenship: How Schools Can Help Save Our Democracy (Book)
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the 2023-2024 academic year, Traub visited schools across the United States to see what was happening on the ground.

item.title: The 10 Best Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s top fiction and nonfiction.
item.category: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny (Book)
There Is No Place for Us: Working and Homeless in America (Book)
Mother Emanuel: Two Centuries of Race, Resistance, and Forgiveness in One Charleston Church (Book)
A Marriage at Sea: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck (Book)
Wild Thing: A Life of Paul Gauguin (Book)

item.title: Daniel Walker Howe, Historian of Antebellum America, Dies at 88
item.description: He saw the origins of modern America in the years between 1815 and 1848, when revolutions in technology and media transformed a nation of isolated farms.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Famed Nigerian Author Blames Death of Toddler Son on Negligent Care
item.description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie is accusing a private hospital in Lagos of administering an overdose of a sedative, prompting an outpouring of complaints by Nigerians about their health care system.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Ismail Auwal
item.media:credit: Schaun Champion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie at her home in Maryland in February.

item.title: Erich von Däniken, Who Claimed Aliens Visited Earth, Dies at 90
item.description: His 1968 book, “Chariots of the Gods,” sold hundreds of thousands of copies, but one critic called it a “warped parody of reasoning.”
item.dc:creator: Mike Peed
item.media:description: Mr. von Däniken’s first and most successful books sold hundreds of thousands of copies, and inspired documentaries, comic books and a movie.

item.title: In “Strangers,” Belle Burden Goes Deep on the End of Her Marriage
item.description: Belle Burden shook off her natural reserve to turn her viral divorce essay into “Strangers,” a bracing memoir.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: Strangers: A Memoir of a Marriage (Book)
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

item.title: George Saunders Says Ditching These Three Delusions Can Save You
item.description: The celebrated author on the challenges of being kind, the benefits of meditation and the reality check of death.
item.dc:creator: David Marchese
item.media:credit: Philip Montgomery for The New York Times

item.title: Unpacking ‘People We Meet on Vacation’ with Emily Henry, Emily Bader and Tom Blyth
item.description: The author and the actors Emily Bader and Tom Blyth explain why the movie differs from the novel and raise the possibility of spinoffs.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer and Jennelle Fong
item.media:description: Henry said a lot of the actor casting suggestions gave her pause. “After Bader and Blyth were cast, she said, “that’s when I was like, ‘It’s going to be OK.’”

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Old Fire,’ by Elisa Shua Dusapin
item.description: “The Old Fire,” an atmospheric new novel by Elisa Shua Dusapin, evokes unresolved family history with subtle heat.
item.dc:creator: Idra Novey

item.title: Rare Comic Introducing Superman Sells Privately for $15 Million
item.description: The copy of Action Comics No. 1, published in 1938, was stolen from the actor Nicolas Cage in 2000 and recovered more than a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Andrew Wilson/Metropolis Collectibles Inc, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A copy of the comic that introduced Superman in 1938. Fewer than 100 copies are known to exist.

item.title: Jerome Lowenstein, 92, Dies; Teaching Doctor With a Literary Sideline
item.description: When not guiding students in a compassionate approach to patient care, he led a tiny publishing imprint that put out a much-rejected debut novel that won a surprise Pulitzer Prize.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: ‘The Correspondent’ Author Virginia Evans Talks About Her Breakout Novel
item.description: Evans’s epistolary tale, about a retired lawyer who spends her days writing to a series of pen pals, became one of last year’s sleeper hits.
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Inset cover: via Crown

item.title: Book Review: ‘Three Stories of Forgetting,’ by Djaimilia Pereira de Almeida
item.description: In a trilogy of novellas, a writer explores lives haunted by colonialism and slavery.
item.dc:creator: Alejandro Chacoff

item.title: How Americans Learned to Love Thomas Paine
item.description: His “Common Sense,” published 250 years ago, ignited the drive for American independence. That was hardly the end of the radical founder’s strange and winding story.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:description: Thomas Paine, whose 1776 pamphlet “Common Sense” helped spark the American Revolution, was hailed by some as the greatest radical of the age and reviled by others as a rabble-rousing atheist.

item.title: Read These 3 Books Before Watching the Movie
item.description: Jennifer Harlan, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, recommends three books to read before their film adaptation releases this year.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan, Edward Vega and June Kim

item.title: Photographers Who Make Picture Books, From Edward Steichen and Tana Hoban to William Wegman
item.description: Pioneered by Edward Steichen, Lewis W. Hine and Tana Hoban, photographically illustrated “concept” books have never had a more potentially receptive audience.
item.dc:creator: Leonard S. Marcus
item.category: How Are You Peeling? Foods With Moods (Book)
From the Mundane to the Magical: Photographically Illustrated Childrens Books, 1854-1945 and Beyond (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘Sheer,’ by Vanessa Lawrence
item.description: In “Sheer,” the novelist Vanessa Lawrence imagines the improbable rise and inglorious fall of a self-made Gen X beauty mogul.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Palmer

item.title: 5 New Books We Love This Week
item.description: Reading recommendations from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: American Reich: A Murder in Orange County, Neo-Nazis, and a New Age of Hate (Book)
Advance Britannia: The Epic Story of the Second World War, 1942-1945 (Book)
This Is Where the Serpent Lives (Book)
The Spy in the Archive: How One Man Tried to Kill the KGB (Book)

item.title: Interview: Tilda Swinton on Her Favorite Books and Favorite Collaborators
item.description: Starring in the 1992 film adaptation helped launch an eclectic career. “Ongoing” is the book that accompanies a retrospective on her work.

item.title: Dav Pilkey, the Man Behind ‘Dog Man,’ Aims to Please
item.description: “I’m writing for the kid I used to be,” says Dav Pilkey, who defied expectations to create three blockbuster graphic-novel series.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Kevin Serna for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Dog Man” fans flocked to a South Bend auditorium in costume, hoping to set a world record and to meet the author Dav Pilkey.

item.title: Philip Yancey, Prominent Christian Author, Admits to Extramarital Affair
item.description: He said he would retire from writing and public speaking.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: St. Petersburg Times/Zuma Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Philip Yancey has been married to his wife, Janet, for 55 years.

item.title: The Most Beautiful Home Libraries T Magazine Has Covered
item.description: From Connecticut to Cairo, reading spots that will seem like paradise to book- and design-lovers alike.
item.dc:creator: T Magazine

item.title: New Nonfiction Books to Read This Year
item.description: Memoirs by Sylvester Stallone and the founder of Barstool Sports; essays from celebrated novelists Jesmyn Ward and Jayne Anne Phillips; and more.
item.dc:creator: Miguel Salazar and Laura Thompson

item.title: New Novels to Read This Year
item.description: Tayari Jones, Ann Patchett, George Saunders and Veronica Roth return with new novels; Jennette McCurdy makes her fiction debut; and more.
item.dc:creator: Miguel Salazar and Laura Thompson

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Machado Will Publish a New Book
item.description: “The Freedom Manifesto,” by María Corina Machado, will lay out the Nobel laureate’s vision for a “new era,” its publisher said.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, will put out her proposals for a “new era” for Venezuela in a book next month.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Spy in the Archive,’ by Gordon Corera
item.description: In his enthralling “The Spy in the Archive,” Gordon Corera tells the story of an unlikely hero embedded within the heart of the agency.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan
item.category: The Spy in the Archive: How One Man Tried to Kill the KGB (Book)
item.media:credit: Lorenzo Di Cola/NurPhoto, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Vasili Mitrokhin was an ordinary Russian who hated what his country had become. This is his story.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Watching Over Her,’ by Jean-Baptiste Andrea
item.description: In the Goncourt winner “Watching Over Her,” Jean-Baptiste Andrea traces the personal and political entanglements of a sculptor whose swagger belies his physical stature.
item.dc:creator: Alex Preston

item.title: Book Review: ‘Advance Britannia,’ by Alan Allport
item.description: In “Advance Britannia,” Alan Allport shows the fighting from the perspective of England and its colonies.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Peraino
item.category: Advance Britannia: The Epic Story of the Second World War, 1942-1945 (Book)
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: In 1945, the British prime minister Winston Churchill traveled to the ruins of Adolf Hitler’s bunker in Berlin and sat in what the Soviets said was the Nazi leader’s chair.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Architect of New York,’ by Javier Moro
item.description: Javier Moro’s new novel focuses on a 19th-century architect who left an indelible imprint on the city.
item.dc:creator: John Freeman Gill

item.title: Book Review: ‘This Is Where the Serpent Lives,’ by Daniyal Mueenuddin
item.description: “This Is Where the Serpent Lives,” by Daniyal Mueenuddin, recalls the power of Russian classics.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.category: This Is Where the Serpent Lives (Book)

item.title: The Most Anticipated Book Adaptations of 2026: Movies and TV Shows
item.description: “People We Meet on Vacation,” “Wuthering Heights” and “Project Hail Mary” are some of this year’s most anticipated adaptations.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan
